Graphical abstract This review presents recent in situ FTIR spectroscopy contributions to lithium-ion batteries and other battery systems. It details the advantages of using in situ FTIR spectroscopy technique to study different battery systems and spectro-electrochemical cells. This technique can hopefully become a protocol for supporting the design of novel materials for batteries. In situ and operando infrared spectroscopies are powerful techniques to support the design of novel materials for batteries and the development of new battery systems. These techniques can support the study of batteries by identifying the formation of new species and monitoring electrochemical energy stability. However, few works have employed these techniques, which can be used to investigate various materials, including systems beyond lithium-ion technology, in the research of batteries. Therefore, this review presents a comprehensive overview focusing on the main contributions of in situ and operando infrared spectroscopy for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and other battery systems. These techniques can successfully identify the formation of species during the electrolyte reduction, electrode degradation, and the formation of the solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer. From these outcomes, it is possible to conclude that this characterization approach should be employed as a protocol to overcome remaining issues in batteries, consequently supporting battery research. This review aims to be a guide on how infrared spectroscopy can contribute to monitoring battery systems and to lead researchers interested in applying this technique. Keywords In situ spectroscopy Operando spectroscopy FTIR Spectro-electrochemical cells Batteries 1 Introduction Batteries are energy storage devices that convert the energy released by chemical reactions into electricity. These devices play a pivotal role in several applications, such as power portable electronics, electric vehicles (EVs), satellites, medical devices, and stationary systems for renewable energies [1–3]. Due to these expanding markets, improving their energy and power densities, cycle life, cost, and the use of more environmentally friendly components is necessary [4,5]. Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are the most commercialized energy storage devices, since they show significant advantages in energy storage efficiency and scale flexibility [1–3]. Basically, LIBs allow lithium ion mobility from one electrode to the other (i.e., insertion and extraction). Ion mobility in liquid electrolytes is a crucial factor in the battery performance and consists of two processes: mobility of the electronic charges and of the solvated ions in the electrolyte solvent [6]. These processes can address problems such as oxidation of the positive electrode, formation of metallic lithium over the negative electrode, and electrolyte electro-reduction [7]. In addition to ion mobility, the selection of materials for the electrodes significantly impacts the cell voltage, cyclability, and capacity of LIBs. Therefore, the further investigation of LIBs electrode, electrolyte, and its interphase as the solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer must be conducted to support the architectural design of advanced materials, enabling the design of novel LIB systems and systems beyond Li-ion electrochemistry [8,9]. Apart from LIBs, researchers have been increasingly interested in batteries with chemistry beyond Li-ion technology, to improve their performances, reduce costs, and diversify systems for different applications [10], including Li-air [11], Li-S [12], and Na-ion [13]. In this complex scenario, where several different devices and a myriad of materials and experimental conditions coexist, in situ and operando techniques are powerful approaches, allowing for an in-depth understanding of the storage mechanism of a cell, the degradation processes of electrode and electrolyte, the changes during operation, and several other fundamental questions about the different battery components, assisting in the development of improved devices [14]. The expressions “in situ” and “operando” have been widely used in spectroscopy to characterize catalysts. In situ analysis refers to real-time analysis under conditions similar to a battery, whereas operando analysis is conducted under the dynamic polarization conditions of a real battery [15]. On the other hand, ex situ analysis characterizes the system outside the cell before or after the use, which is a valuable approach but is limited in some cases for several reasons, among which: (i) showing only two pictures of the entire process (beginning and end), being unable to show a correlation between the multiple events that can occur during a process and the changes observed; (ii) needing the removal of the material from the electrochemical ambient, which means the changes observed can be caused by the lack of electrochemical control (potential or current); (iii) similar to the last point, exposing the material, after removal from the electrochemical ambient, depending on the technique, to the presence of the atmosphere, inert gas, vacuum, etc., which can modify the material that was previously in contact with a different substance or material, likely the electrolyte [15,16]. Among the several available in situ characterization techniques, this study focuses on Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy, which can support the analysis of the SEI layer, presenting valuable information about the composition of this region in batteries [17–27]. Furthermore, in situ and operando characterizations have also been used to identify degradation processes [28], track physical, and electrochemical changes [14]. Spectroscopic techniques significantly contribute to the study of energy storage devices, monitoring molecular changes of the investigated materials. Among these techniques, FTIR spectroscopy is a surface-sensitive technique, suitable for investigating structural changes on interfaces. Unlike FTIR spectroscopy, other techniques like X-ray diffraction (XRD) are not surface sensitive. In contrast, they can identify changes in the bulk of the materials [29]. Both FTIR and Raman spectroscopies are vibrational techniques [30], which several times may complement each other, but FTIR spectroscopy is generally able to study more systems due to its higher sensitivity [31]. Furthermore, conventional FTIR spectrometers are cheaper than Raman spectrometers and XRD diffractometers, and are available worldwide in most chemistry, physics, and engineering institutes [32]. Although in situ FTIR spectroscopy has been extensively applied in electrocatalysis [33–35], there are fewer examples in the field of batteries. Fig. 1 shows recent advances in the study of battery systems by in situ or operando FTIR spectroscopy and a brief background of in situ FTIR spectroscopy, starting with the Michelson [36] and Michelson-Morley [37] experiments conducted in the 19th century. Their efforts enabled the further development of the first commercial infrared spectrometer able to calculate the fast Fourier transform (FFT), released in 1969 by Digilab Inc. [38]. In situ FTIR spectroscopy was pioneered by Bewick, who conducted a study monitoring structural changes on a platinum electrode during an electrocatalytic oxidation reaction reported in 1983 [39]. Furthermore, in 1991, Aurbach and Gofer showed the use of in situ FTIR spectroscopy to monitor the reduction process of carbonate solvates to form ROCO2Li in a lithium battery system [40]. These authors presented a spectro-electrochemical cell (SEC), which was used to monitor electrochemical reactions of electrolytes comprising carbonate solvents and lithium salts on the surface of noble metal electrodes [41]. This contribution was essential for further employing FTIR spectroscopy to monitor these processes under polarization conditions. These advances are detailed in the timeline shown in Fig. 1, which details important achievements of infrared spectroscopy until the design of modern SECs used to conduct in situ analysis (see Section 2 for more details on this topic). Furthermore, other significant efforts have been reported, such as the design of modern SECs (Fig. 1a–e), which have particular advantages. Among the SECs developed in the last decade, the one presented by Masui et al. [21] has successfully monitored the formation of the SEI layer on the negative electrode of LIBs in half-cell configurations (Fig. 1a). Moreover, SECs have been used to study systems beyond lithium-ion technology, such as Li-S batteries investigated by Saqib et al. [42] (Fig. 1b), which enabled to monitor the concentration and order of lithium polysulfides, contributing to the study of novel cathodes. SECs with different setups have also been investigated, such as the spectro-electrochemical pouch cell (SEPC) presented by Vizintin et al. [43] (Fig. 1c), being used to study cathodes for metal-organic batteries. Also, some SECs are used to conduct in situ synchrotron infrared nano-spectroscopy (SINS), such as the study presented by Nepel et al., which reported that an SEC was employed to study degradation reactions of a carbon electrode of a Li-air system by in situ SINS [44] (Fig. 1d). Versatile SECs have also been reported in the literature, such as the SEC developed by Bott-Neto et al. [45], enabling different spectroscopy techniques by replacing the optical window (Fig. 1e). The literature shows several reviews related to the application of in situ and operando characterization techniques for the study of batteries [29,46–48]. However, these reviews have not focused on FTIR spectroscopy, and, as stated before, in situ and operando FTIR spectroscopy techniques are not widespread in battery research. In this context, it is timely to present a review showing the most important experimental approaches used to study materials applied in batteries by in situ FTIR spectroscopy, and then describe some successful examples in the field and the setups available to perform these experiments, which could certainly offer an idea of how this technique can contribute to the field of batteries. Therefore, herein, this review describes some fundamentals of in situ FTIR spectroscopy (Section 2.1), advances in the design of SECs for in situ FTIR spectroscopy (Section 2.2), and some case studies of in situ FTIR spectroscopy applied for LIBs, lithium-sulfur (Li-S), metal-organic, magnesium-metal (Mg-metal), lithium-air (Li-air), zinc-air (Zn-air), zinc-nitrogen (Zn-N2), and sodium-ion (SIBs) batteries (Section 3). Finally, the last section of this review is the conclusion (Section 4). 2 Fundamentals of infrared spectroscopy in the study of electrochemical systems 2.1 In situ FTIR spectroscopy techniques In situ FTIR spectroscopy is an efficient tool to characterize the electrode-electrolyte interface in electrochemical systems since it can monitor concentration changes of molecules/ions and charged or neutral adsorbed species on the material under the influence of the electrochemical potential [49]. Generally, three configurations are typically used to minimize the absorption of IR radiation from the electrolyte species during in situ FTIR experiments (Fig. 2 ): (i) Infrared Reflection-Absorption Spectroscopy (IRAS), (ii) attenuated total reflection (ATR), and (iii) diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). In the IRAS configuration (Fig. 2a), the working electrode (WE) is pressed against the window (or prism) to form a thin layer of electrolyte in the space between the WE and the window (or prism), guaranteeing increased IR intensity at the electrode surface and the detector. This setup allows the use of various materials as electrodes, including bulk, micro, and nanomaterials (single crystals, nano-oxides, carbon materials, etc.). Besides that, it enables simultaneous determination of adsorbed and dissolved species in the reaction while the mass transport is restricted in the thin layer [49]. On the other hand, this configuration presents some important limitations, namely: (i) the electrode must present good reflectance since the beam is reflected by the material and then guided to the detector, and (ii) the measurement can generate conductivity problems and polarization by diffusion since it is performed in a thin layer. Thus, the researcher must carefully choose the experimental parameters to get reliable information that can be used to understand the material performance in a real device. Bott-Neto et al. have already discussed this issue by using experimental measurements and simulations [45]. In the ATR configuration (Fig. 2b), the WE is frequently a thin film (<100 nm) of metal (Au, Pt, Pd, etc.) deposited on the surface of a non-conductor and transparent prism with a high refractive index [49]. The IR radiation reaches the interface from the prism side, not the solution side. Therefore, the loss of radiation intensity due to absorption from the electrolyte is significantly decreased, which is typically a disadvantage in the IRAS configuration. In this setup, evanescent waves interact with the species in the electrode/electrolyte interface; in the case of a trapezoid prism, multiple internal reflections occur. The WE surface area is also bigger, which improves the signal/noise ratio and helps detect low concentrations of the adsorbed species [50]. Some advantages of the ATR compared with the IRAS configuration are: (i) higher sensitivity to adsorbed species, (ii) small interference from the electrolyte bulk, and (iii) lower ohmic drop and transport limitations [51]. However, the concepts described have been more explored in the field of electrocatalysis than in the field of batteries. It is possible to see in the following sections, regarding battery research, that the prisms have been used as electrodes only in studies involving silicon (Si), where a Si prism was used [25]. In general, the prisms used in the ATR configuration are not components of the batteries and are simply used to conduct the IR light on its surface. Thus, the material under study is pressed against the surface of the prism to interact with the IR beam. This configuration allows in situ and operando studies with sandwich-like batteries. Finally, DRIFTS configuration can also be used for in situ FTIR experiments. In DRIFTS, the beam interacts with a powder or a surface with high roughness and is reflected in all directions, i.e., the so-called diffuse reflectance [52]. This approach is an interesting alternative to IRAS for surfaces with low reflectivity. Like in IRAS, if the configuration of the cell or the necessity of the experiment requires that the beam travels to the solution before and after reflecting on the surface, performing experiments in the thin layer configuration is also important. Hence this system shows the same drawbacks. However, since this approach is preferable for surfaces with poor reflectance, experiments in the thin layer configuration are frequently avoided since the problems will likely be more serious than for IRAS. On the other hand, DRIFTS is useful for analyzing rough surfaces that are directly irradiated without needing to cross any liquid phase, as shown in Fig. 2(c). Therefore, the technique is especially suitable for studying sandwich-like batteries or capacitors [53]. In summary, the main advantage of using in situ DRIFTS in battery research is to study electrodes with rough and/or irregular surfaces and to follow the formation of the SEI layer, whereas the main disadvantage is the reproducibility of the experiments since the surface will not be the same for each experiment [54]. 2.2 Spectro-electrochemical cells for in situ and operando FTIR spectroscopy As previously stressed, in situ FTIR analyses in electrochemical systems have been performed using the IRAS, ATR, or DRIFTS configuration to avoid the generally high IR radiation absorption from the electrolyte [19–21,24,42,55–57]. Thus, home-made or commercial accessories are used to deviate the IR beam from the spectrometer to the SEC (hitting the working electrode) and from the SEC to the detector [58]. Most SECs used for in situ FTIR spectroscopy are designed to prevent atmospheric interferences during analysis [26,59]. Thus, the SECs might be closed with several IR transparent windows or prism, which can be made of CaF2 [17,24,60], ZnSe [20,59], diamond [26,61], BaF2 [57,62], and Si wafer [43]. Besides, since the devices will probably be used in several environments (for instance, different electrolytes), Teflon and polyether ether ketone (PEEK) are often used as the SEC body materials due to their relatively high chemical resistance [19,20,24,45,57,59,62]. Furthermore, since the devices contain liquids, chemically and mechanically resistant O-rings are essential to seal the cell and prevent leakage [20,45,59]. Besides, since several materials for batteries are sensitive to contact with air, the SEC must be designed to enable easy assembly inside a glove box [17,24,42,44,59,63,64]. Finally, depending on the aim of the experiment, the SECs may contain two [21,42,43] or three [55,65] electrodes. The former approach is generally used in operando experiments, whereas the latter is preferred when the experiment requires the presence of a reference electrode in a more fundamental approach. Several efforts have been made to develop novel SECs, aiming to design novel approaches for conducting in situ and operando FTIR spectroscopy of electrochemical systems, as summarized by Fig. 1, which shows some important contributions to the design of SECs, presenting several of the characteristics previously described. Bott-Neto et al. designed a versatile conventional three-electrode SEC for in situ FTIR external reflection spectroscopy, which provided a simple replacement of the WE and optical window, allowing for the use of several spectroscopy techniques such as Raman and XRD. This SEC, detailed in Fig. 1(e), also enables experiments under flow conditions with adaptations through the electrolyte inlet and outlet [45]. The SECs employed for in situ FTIR spectroscopy via the reflectance mode, both IRAS and ATR, can be vertically assembled in a schematic similar to a coin cell [18,21,24,42,61], therefore allowing a better simulation of the situation in a real device. For instance, Yang et al. introduced a novel SEC setup to conduct ATR-FTIR experiments to monitor the electrode surface. The authors presented this novel SEC in a sandwich setup with an ultra-small electrolyte volume (i.e., lower than 0.1 mL) [18]. Following the same idea, Saqib et al. developed an SEC similar to a coin cell with a configuration even more similar to a real system that presented a centered hole in both the positive electrode and separator. The positive electrode was placed directly over the ATR crystal, facilitating the IR beam entrance into the cell (see the detailed schematic in Fig. 1b) [42]. Beyond the SECs with setups similar to a coin cell, Vizintin et al. presented a novel SEPC (see Fig. 1c). This cell configuration is suitable for powering cell phones and portable electronics, and the SEPC presented by Vizintin et al. demonstrated the feasibility of investigating the reaction on the cathode of redox-active polymers and, thus, getting valuable information regarding battery reversibility and stability [43]. The approaches proposed by Vizintin et al. [43] and by Saqib et al. [42] present some similarities, such as the position of the electrode of interest (for both, the cathode), which was pressed against a Si wafer window (transparent to IR radiation) in the approach presented by Vizintin et al. [43] and on an ATR crystal (Fig. 1c) in the approach proposed by Saqib et al. [42]. In summary, this section showed that several SECs have been proposed to study changes in the SEI and the electrolyte bulk by FTIR spectroscopy. Interestingly, this review shows SECs reported in the literature for in situ FTIR spectroscopy, such as a conventional electrochemical three-electrode cell used for several applications, and coin-like and pouched-like SECs (Fig. 1), which are more challenging to use, but are specially designed to simulate batteries environment. Thus, researchers in the field of batteries and supercapacitors can hopefully use these approaches to study both conventional and more advanced systems. Therefore, in the next section, there is the description of the structure and importance of the SEI layer, to then describe some important successful cases of FTIR spectroscopy application for studying LIBs, Li-S, metal-organic, Mg-metal, Li-air, Zn-air, Zn-N2, and SIBs. These examples and the cells discussed here can hopefully encourage researchers to develop this type of study and offer more detailed information about the microscopic processes determining their systems capacity and stability. More details about how to adapt a conventional FTIR spectrometer for in situ experiments in the electrochemistry field and how to set different SEC for IRAS and ATR experiments can be found elsewhere [66]. 3 In situ and operando FTIR spectroscopy on batteries research The SEI layer is a key component of a battery, highly impacting its performance. On this aspect of the device, it can be considered that one of the main in situ FTIR spectroscopy contributions is the better comprehension of the SEI formation and the effect of the electrolyte and electrodes on it. Since the terms in situ and operando are misinterpreted in the literature, these analyses will be mentioned in this review as in situ, only for simplicity. There are several important works monitoring the SEI layer formation on LIB systems [18–21,23–27]. The SEI layer culminates from reactions between the electrolyte and the negative electrode, which is mainly composed of electrolyte decomposition species [67]. In summary, for a conventional LIB, lithium ions are inserted into the electrode material without their solvation shell (created by the organic molecules) during the charging process, forming the interlayer, i.e., the SEI layer. This process is known as desolvation, in which the lithium ions are desolvated and diffused into the SEI layer, which is an interfacial passivation layer on the carbon electrode during the initial stage (i.e., activation charge or initial charge). The initial charge decomposes the carbon surface from the electrolyte, forming the SEI layer, which is essential for electrode stability (see a schematic of the SEI layer formation in Fig. 3 ). Without the SEI layer on the anode surface, the lithium ions would reach the negative carbon electrode with the solvation shell, exfoliate the graphite layers, and degrade the material [68,69]. In this sense, an adequate SEI layer can improve the battery performance by preventing dendrites formation, reducing surface roughness, and decreasing side reactions between the interface of the electrolyte and the electrode [9]. A complete understanding of the SEI layer, which behaves as an electronic insulator and ionic conductor, is still lacking [67]. The electrolyte solvents should be carefully selected to provide a reasonable solvation shell for lithium ions, since it stabilizes the formation of the SEI layer [70–72]. Also, the SEI layer must be chemically stable and should not present cracks as the electrode volume increases and decreases during cycling [9]. The SEI layer formation consumes approximately 10% of the total lithium, culminating in an irreversible capacity decrease. Using electrolyte additives can improve the SEI layer formation on negative electrodes [73–75]. Thus, the efficiency of electrolyte additives can be evaluated by in situ FTIR spectroscopy since it enables realistic monitoring of the SEI layer of battery cells, as shown in the study by Matsui et al. [21], which investigated the efficiency of electrolyte additives by monitoring the SEI layer formation. Battery electrolytes containing additives [e.g., lithium bis(oxalate)borate (LiBOB)] show a thicker SEI layer than the SEI layer formed in additive-free electrolytes, and the SEI mechanism may be associated with the electrolyte additive decomposition (e.g., LiBOB and solvent molecules) [21]. The negative electrode is directly correlated with the SEI layer formation, which affects the performance of battery devices. A negative graphite electrode from a conventional LIB system shows a small volume extension, usually less than 7%, during lithiation and delithiation processes, providing appropriate electrical and mechanical stability. The small volume expansion of graphite in LIBs maintains a minor strain in the SEI layer. On the other hand, a higher volume expansion would crack the SEI layer, consequently reducing the electrolyte at a low potential and restricting its performance and cycling by an unsteady consumption of lithium ions [76], since volume expansion may culminate in an unstable SEI layer [68]. Unsatisfactory conductivity and structural volume expansion are common obstacles that need improvement in the negative electrodes of batteries [8]. Therefore, this review presents recent contributions to the application of in-situ FTIR spectroscopy in the study of novel materials for LIBs and other battery systems. There are several examples in the following section, aiming to show the contributions that in situ FTIR spectroscopy can offer to understand microscopic events in the field of batteries, focusing on the processes (charge, discharge, etc.) and substances (electrode, electrolyte, etc.) instead of making a description of bands appearing and disappearing at different wavenumbers and constructing huge tables connecting molecules or substances to bands, aiming to provide a comprehensive review. Besides, it is important to avoid contributing to the incorrect approach of doing a band assignment based on literature tables without paying attention to the conditions in which such spectra have been taken. Whenever possible, researchers must take the infrared spectra in the standard conditions, as similar as possible to those from in situ FTIR experiments, highly increasing the suitability of the band assignment, which is crucial for interpreting the results. 3.1 Lithium-ion batteries 3.1.1 Characterization of interfacial reactions on negative electrodes The negative electrode in LIBs does not limit the battery capacity, but the SEI is a key aspect of their long-cycling behavior, as previously highlighted. Apart from the importance of SEI characterization, the emergence of metal-based anodes has also been recently re-ignited as a promising direction for future research [77,78]. Lithium-metal is an interesting choice for negative electrodes due to its specific charge of 3862 A h kg−1, lightness, its negative redox potential of −3.05 vs. standard hydrogen electrode (SHE), and gravimetric energy exceeding 600 W h kg−1. However, lithium-metal presents some restrictions, such as the formation of dendrites [79], which can result in short circuits [80]. Efforts have been made to minimize the dendrite formation and risk of flammability, such as the use of polymer-based electrolytes, which also provides flexibility to the battery and electrical conductivity [81,82]. FTIR spectroscopy is a plausible alternative to support the study of novel polymer-based electrolytes for lithium-metal batteries, since it can monitor the formation and structural changes of the SEI layer formed between the negative lithium-metal electrode and the electrolyte [67]. Among the materials used as negative electrodes for LIBs, carbonaceous materials have been predominantly used in commercial LIBs [77,83], particularly graphite [84]. Several studies have used in situ FTIR spectroscopy to investigate negative electrodes of LIBs [20,21,59,63]. In situ FTIR spectroscopy can also support the study of electrolyte additives, which can improve the SEI layer formation on the surface of the negative electrode, as discussed in Section 3 [21]. In this context, Matsui et al. used in situ ATR-FTIR spectroscopy to monitor the formation of the SEI on a negative graphite electrode and the effects of an electrolyte additive during this process. In this study, the researchers compared the resulting FTIR spectra obtained during the first cycle of two different battery cells whose systems comprised different electrolytes: (i) an additive-free electrolyte (Fig. 4 ai) and (ii) an electrolyte containing 5 wt% of LiBOB as an additive (Fig. 4aii). Based on the FTIR spectra, the SEI layer contains ether-based species in the absence of the additive. On the other hand, the consumption (reaction) of LiBOB and the presence of C–O bands have been observed in the SEI layer. Besides, the FTIR spectra showed that the system with the electrolyte containing the LiBOB additive presented bands with higher intensities than the additive-free electrolyte, indicating that the use of electrolyte additives can provide a thicker SEI layer than additive-free electrolytes (Fig. 4aii) [21]. Furthermore, Haregewoin et al. used in situ DRIFTS to monitor the SEI layer formation process on the surface of mesocarbon microbead (MCMB) negative electrode by tracking electrolyte reduction products. Particularly, ethylene carbonate (EC) reduction formed (CH2OCO2Li)2 and Li2CO3, and the diethyl carbonate (DEC) reduction formed CH3CH2OCO2Li and Li2CO3. Spectra were obtained during cyclic voltammetry (CV) and acquired at the potentials of 2.5, 1.8, 1.2, 0.8, 0.6, 0.4, and 0.2 V vs. Li. Therefore, this approach allowed the authors to get detailed structural information of the SEI layer formed on the MCMB electrode [59]. Other suitable alternatives for negative electrodes of LIBs include Si, tin (Sn)-based materials, composite alloys, and three-dimensional-metal oxide materials [77]. Si has demonstrated high capacity, and several previous researchs have used in situ FTIR spectroscopy to investigate the Si electrode-electrolyte interface [18,20,25]. However, Si negative electrodes may present high volume expansion when completely charged, and they show irreversible fractures during continuous lithiation and delithiation processes [85], resulting in massive capacity loss after long cyclability [86]. Therefore, Shi et al. used in situ ATR-FTIR spectroscopy to monitor the stability of a negative Si electrode by tracking structural changes in the solid-electrolyte interphase. The authors monitored the electrocatalytic reduction of DEC on the Si-oxide layer of the electrode during spectro-electrochemical analysis. This reduction process culminated in the formation of diethyl 2,5-dioxahexane dicarboxylate (DEDOHC), which is formed due to a reaction between EC molecules with ethoxide radical anion (CH3–CH2–O–) intermediates. The results also indicated that lithium ethylene dicarbonate (LiEDC) production primarily occurred on lithiated Si due to continuous cracking. The spectra showed the presence of DEDOHC on the surface of the Si electrode, which was evidenced by the decrease in the intensity of the bands assigned to DEDOHC during the initial lithiation cycle, which was followed by electrolyte reduction. Furthermore, the spectra from the 5th and 10th cycles showed the formation of LiEDC (Fig. 4b), whereas DEDOHC bands vanished from the spectra. Overall, in situ ATR-FTIR spectra showed that the SEI composition changed from DEDOHC-prevailing to a LiEDC-prevailing layer according to the number of cycles [20]. The use of organic-based materials as the negative electrodes of LIBs systems is another interesting option, since these materials can store lithium ions, presenting high charge storage capacity, redox stability, and being considered eco-friendly [87]. However, the dissolution of organic species in Li-based electrolytes results in rapid capacity fade during the cycling process. Therefore, more research is needed to find novel organic species with high energy density and cycling stability to design novel organic materials for LIBs. Among organic materials, π-conjugated aromatic compounds that contain heteroatoms have shown promising results. For instance, Xia et al. investigated a π-conjugated N-containing heteroaromatic hexacarboxylate (lithium hexaazatriphenylene hexacarboxylate) (Li6-HAT) as a negative electrode for an LIB system. In summary, in situ FTIR spectroscopy is able to track the charge storage mechanism of the Li6-HAT electrode, which has demonstrated high reversibility during lithiation processes [63]. 3.1.2 Characterization of interfacial reactions on positive electrodes Traditional positive electrodes of LIBs contain transition metal oxides (e.g., Co, Mn, Ni, and Fe) as their active material [5,88]. Commercial LIBs usually mix the active material with a binder (e.g., PVDF), a conductive additive (e.g., carbon black), and a solvent (e.g., N-methyl pyrrolidinone, NMP), forming a slurry that is coated on a substrate and further dried [89–92]. Generally, LiCoO2 (LCO) is used as the positive electrode of LIBs, but there is a concern regarding the origin of cobalt, being used for producing LCO electrodes. Cobalt presents an unstable supply chain, and most of its mining involves precarious working conditions in situations similar to slave labor [93]. Some alternatives of high-capacity cobalt-free materials for use as the cathodes of LIBs are reported, such as LiFePO4 (LFP) [77] and LiMn2O4 (LMO) [94]. Furthermore, LiNi x Mn y Co z O2 (NMC) is another alternative for high-capacity positive electrodes; despite having cobalt in its structure, it comprises less than 5% of this material, which is a significantly low amount [77,95]. The design of these novel alternative materials to replace LCO-based cathodes can be supported by in situ FTIR spectroscopy, which has been used to study the (positive) electrode-electrolyte interphase [21]. Norberg and Kostecki used in situ ATR-FTIR spectroscopy to study a LiMnPO4 (LMP) electrode under polarization conditions, monitoring carbonyl groups and the influence of the electrode PVDF binder on the (positive) electrode-electrolyte interphase. The spectra indicated shifts of a band assigned to PO4 3− and the formation of a novel band also attributed to PO4 3− during the delithiation process. However, the LMO electrode absorption bands did not fully disappear, which is in accordance with the final result of the state-of-charge (SOC) of 96 mA h g−1, approximately 57% of the electrode theoretical capacity. The formation of lithium alkyl carbonates (RCO3Li, with R as an alkyl group) on the surface layer of the LiMnPO4 electrode has also been identified by in situ FTIR spectroscopy, which was considered a direct evidence of the formation of the (positive) electrode-electrolyte layer [96]. Furthermore, Matsui et al. used in situ ATR-FTIR spectroscopy to investigate the LiMn2O4 spinel positive electrode interface in an LIB system during the charge-discharge process (Fig. 5 ai). The in situ spectra indicated the formation of new bands during the charging and discharging processes of the SEC, as shown in Fig. 5(aii and aiii), respectively. The initial charge spectrum (Fig. 5aii) and the last discharge spectrum (Fig. 5aiii) presented higher intensity bands than those recorded at intermediate charge states, indicating that the overpotentials applied in the electrode influenced the adsorption of the solvent molecules (i.e., carbonyl bonds). The last spectrum from the charging process displayed bands with lower intensities than those in previous spectra acquired during the charging process (Fig. 5ai), indicating that the lithium concentration was stabilized due to the fast lithium ion diffusion on the electrode [21]. In situ ATR-FTIR spectroscopy can also be employed to identify parasitic reactions between NMC electrodes and a carbonate electrolyte [24]. Previous research has used NMC as another layered lithium metal oxide for positive electrodes, providing high capacity. Results have shown that the initial discharge capacity could be significantly high for Ni-rich NMC electrode materials [97–99]. However, capacity retention may decrease throughout the cycling [97], followed by an initial gas onset, such as O2 and CO2 formation [100,101]. Therefore, Zhang et al. used ATR-FTIR spectroscopy to understand the oxidation reaction of NMC powder electrodes in different electrolytes from a microscopic point of view [24]. They analyzed the electrolyte reactivity with NMC811 and LiNi0.1Co0.1Mn0.1O2 (NMC111) electrodes using in situ ATR-FTIR spectroscopy (Fig. 5bii–iv). The species resulting from the dehydrogenation of EC, vinylene carbonate (VC), and oligomers containing EC-like rings when charging the NMC811 electrode until 3.8 V vs. Li/Li+ have been identified. The deconvoluted VC bands and oligomers increased according to voltage, implying that these bands were continuously formed from EC and/or dehydrogenated EC (de-H EC), probably due to their consumption to further create VC and oligomers. The electrolyte oxidation through the dehydrogenation of EC on the charged NMC811 electrode was evidenced, potentially causing EC to detach from the electrode surface to extract one hydrogen and form de-H EC, which further extracted one more hydrogen to create VC or associated with another EC to create oligomers. The VC, oligomers, and EC bands quickly decreased with extended time at the open circuit voltage (OCV) (see Fig. 5biv), indicating that these compounds diffused out of the charged NMC811 toward the electrolyte [24,102]. Furthermore, Zhang et al. investigated the oxidation via dehydrogenation of NCM111 and NMC811 electrodes in contact with 1 M LiPF6 in EC/EMC (3:7) (i.e., LP57 electrolyte). Results indicated that the EC solvent from the LP57 electrolyte tended to decrease the dehydrogenation process on the Ni-based oxide electrode since the metal-oxygen covalency was diminished. The spectra of the NMC111 electrode did not show significant changes, indicating the absence of solvent oxidation in this initial charge. Furthermore, the authors used in situ ATR-FTIR spectroscopy to investigate the third cycle of NMC622 and NMC622 covered with Al2O3 electrodes in contact with the LP57 electrolyte. Although the NMC622 electrode had not previously shown traces of carbonate dehydrogenation during the initial cycle, the NMC622 electrode spectra showed the formation of dehydrogenated EC species, which was not observed in the spectra of the NMC622 covered with Al2O3. These results demonstrated that the system containing the NMC622 electrode surface covered with Al2O3 did not presented the dehydrogenation process for the LP57 electrolyte. In summary, based on the FTIR spectroscopy results, Zhang et al. proposed a reaction pathway mechanism for the dehydrogenation process. The authors realized that EMC molecules that have dissociated hydrogen can be adsorbed by the oxide surface. The EC molecules have also been dehydrogenated, culminating in the appearance of de-H EC bonds with the oxide surface. Furthermore, EC can be dehydrogenated again, creating VC. Another route is the oxidation of de-H EC, opening its ring and forming oligomers, such as C6H8O6, C9H14O8, and C7H10O6. The organic species formed from carbonate decomposition can contribute to the evolution of a passivating layer on the oxide surface. The dehydrogenation of the solvents (i.e., EC and EMC) culminates in the formation of protic species on the electrode surface, which can react with the LiPF6 salt, generating species such as HF, Li x PF y O z , transition metal fluorides (MF), and PF3O (Fig. 5bv). The authors also emphasized that undesirable dehydrogenation of the electrolyte solvents can increase the interfacial impedance and decrease the capacity under high voltages [24]. The deeper comprehension of the electrolyte solvent decomposition on the NMC electrode-electrolyte interface indicates that undesirable solvent dehydrogenation—which can contribute to oligomerization and salt decomposition—can be reduced by coating the electrode surface with inert materials, such as ceramic thin films, decreasing the driving force of the solvent dissociation and increasing the system stability. Therefore, the NMC622 electrode coated with Al2O3 showed no apparent solvent decomposition, whereas the NMC without the Al2O3 coating presented EC dehydrogenation after three cycles. Other alternatives to inhibit undesired electrolyte solvent dehydrogenation, such as the addition of electrolyte additives, should also be considered [24], which can also be investigated by in situ FTIR spectroscopy [21]. In summary, in situ FTIR spectroscopy techniques are useful for investigating the interphase of (positive) electrodes-electrolyte. Researchers have been able to observe the stability and reversibility of LIB systems by monitoring positive electrodes with FTIR spectroscopy [21]. This technique also allows monitoring changes during lithium insertion and extraction by observing the interference between polymer binders and decomposed species and the formation of lithium alkyl carbonates on the surface layer of positive electrodes [96]. 3.2 Li-S batteries Li-S battery systems are also promising alternatives [103]. Sulfur is considered a prosperous candidate for electrode material due to its stability, high-energy density, low cost, and high-gravimetric capacitance [104]. Specifically, sulfur presents a theoretical capacity of 1675 mA h g−1 and a theoretical energy density of 2600 W h kg−1 [105], and it is an abundant material with low toxicity [105–107]. However, Li-S batteries present some issues, such as the limited cyclability due to the dissolution of lithium polysulfides (Li2S n ) in the electrolyte, resulting in the loss of active material, as a consequence of the shuttle effect [103,108,109]. In situ FTIR spectroscopy has rarely been applied to investigate Li-S battery systems [42,110,111]. However, the application of in situ ATR-FTIR has demonstrated efficiency in monitoring the electrolyte decomposition in Li-S systems by tracking the molecular bonds of the electrolyte [42,110] and in directly monitoring the concentration and order of dissolved intermediate lithium polysulfides during the cycling processes [42,110,111]. The shuttle effect is a crucial drawback to overcome in Li-S battery systems. It consists of a chain of polysulfides formed in the positive electrode as the charging moves to the negative electrode, culminating in the negative Li-metal electrode corrosion and capacity decrease. This chain can be transferred to the positive electrode and further re-oxidized. Thus, sequenced soluble polysulfides reactions may result in the battery self-discharge [108,112], which is shown in Fig. 6 (a). Therefore, the development of novel positive electrodes for Li-S batteries that can transport electrons to the sulfur electrode and catch polysulfides formed during the discharge is an essential issue. In this context, the use of sulfur host materials capable of adsorbing polysulfides, such as carbon materials [12] and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [113,114], is a plausible alternative. The Li-metal negative electrode of Li-S cells might fail due to the formation of dendrites on its surface [103]. FTIR spectroscopy is a sensitive technique for monitoring molecular changes in the electrode/electrolyte, including the formation of sulfur species, which makes this technique appropriate for studying novel materials for Li-S batteries [115]. Furthermore, ATR-FTIR has demonstrated efficiency in monitoring lithium polysulfides dissolved in electrolytes, their order, and their concentration (Fig. 6b) [42,111]. Saqib et al. investigated the lithium polysulfide formation in a Li-S battery system using in situ ATR-FTIR spectroscopy during a charge-discharge experiment. The resulting spectra displayed reduced and leftward-shifted bands as the cell was discharged (Fig. 6bi) and charged (Fig. 6bii) [42]. The voltage shape previously showed an initial curve from 1.9 to 2.4 V [42], which is assigned to the solid-liquid two-phase reaction of elemental sulfur to Li2S8 [108,116]. The polysulfides order remained stable from 2.4 to 2.2 V, and Li2S8 has been reduced to polysulfides with lower order from 2.2 to 1.9 V. This range indicates a decrease in the polysulfides order, followed by a stable concentration rise. Insoluble polysulfides were also formed [42,108,116]. The polysulfide order was stable during the charging process, and its concentration increased during the initial one-third (1/3) of the initial cycle. Meanwhile, Li2S and LiS2 were oxidized to soluble polysulfide compounds, creating extensive polysulfides as the cell was being charged. The concentration gradually diminished near the end of the cycle, indicating the recovery of the electrolyte crystalline sulfur [42]. The study indicated that in situ ATR-FTIR spectroscopy is an appropriate technique for monitoring lithium polysulfide in Li-S systems [42]. In summary, this in situ approach enabled the quantification of polysulfide concentration and successfully showed that this quantification can be performed as a function of the battery SOC. In situ ATR-FTIR spectroscopy provides a fundamental comprehension of the interactivity with materials that attenuate the shuttle effect [42,117,118]. Therefore, in situ characterization techniques, particularly FTIR spectroscopy, are essential to support the development of novel and stable electrode materials for Li-S battery systems [119]. 3.3 Metal-organic batteries Organic materials have also been investigated as the positive electrodes of lithium batteries [120–122]. Since in situ techniques are not as available as ex situ techniques, electrochemical mechanisms of organic materials are most times investigated by post-mortem analysis. Therefore, to develop novel electrode materials for this system, it is essential to directly monitor electrochemical reactions on organic electrodes of metal-organic batteries by in situ spectroscopies, such as the study conducted by Vizintin et al., which investigated organic electrodes for metal-organic batteries by in situ ATR-FTIR spectroscopy (Fig. 7 a) using an SEPC (Fig. 1c) [43]. In this study, poly(anthraquinonyl sulfide) (PAQS), a redox-active polymer, was investigated as an active cathode for Li metal-organic batteries by in situ ATR-FTIR spectroscopy. The in situ spectra presented some changes in its bands related to the PAQS (Fig. 7b), and bands assigned to C=O stretching vibrations have also been observed (Fig. 7ci). The intensity of C=O bands decreased and increased when the system was discharged and charged, respectively, showing good reversibility of the PAQS-based cathode [43]. Furthermore, the authors subtracted the spectra of the cycled cell from the initial state spectrum, and the difference spectra evidenced a novel high-intensity band at 1370 cm−1 (Fig. 7ci), whose intensity increased during the discharge process. This band is attributed to the –C–O–Li+ bond from the PAQS-based electrode, which was previously observed in the ex situ IR spectrum of 9,10-dihydroxy anthracene (Li2AQ), indicating the formation of anthraquinone (AQ) discharge. Novel ring vibration bonds have been observed, specifically C–H stretching and in-plane C–H bending vibrations, which have also been evidenced by an intense increase in the double band positioned at 1070 and 1050 cm−1 (Fig. 7ci) [43]. In addition, Mg-metal-organic battery systems also present excellent cycle reversibility and have already been investigated [123–125]. Vizintin et al. [43] also investigated an Mg-metal-organic battery system by in situ ATR-FTIR spectroscopy using an SEPC. This system used Mg-metal as the negative electrode and PAQS as the positive electrode. The spectra of the Mg-metal organic system presented some differences from the Li-metal organic system in the fingerprint region of the spectra. The spectra presented in-ring vibration changes attributed to alterations in the PAQS structure, resulting from the intercalation between this material and Mg2+ ions (Fig. 7cii). The Mg-metal organic system showed a lower capacity than the Li-metal organic system. Nevertheless, this system showed appropriate reversibility, as observed in the spectrum of the 24th cycle (Fig. 7cii). Using the PAQS electrode is considered an alternative to upgrading Mg-metal organic batteries [43]. Previously, the electrochemical activity of PAQS in a Li-organic system had already been suggested by Song et al. [122], presenting a detailed mechanism in Fig. 7(ciii), which was further confirmed in the study conducted by Vizintin et al. [43]. 3.4 Mg-metal Batteries As previously discussed, Mg-metal batteries have a low-cost and outstanding energy density. Using Mg-metal as a negative electrode shows a lower possibility of dendrite formation than using Li-metal. Mg-metal batteries also present a volumetric capacity of 3833 mA h cm−3, which is higher than lithium metal. However, novel positive electrodes for Mg-metal batteries should be developed for a cost-effective alternative [126,127], and the design of electrolytes should be further investigated. The electrolyte is essential to prevent the formation of a passivation layer, which is crucial to enable further studies of Mg-metal as a negative electrode. In situ ATR-FTIR spectroscopy can be employed to identify the reversibility of Mg-based batteries. Kuwata et al. monitored electrolyte decomposition reactions in a Mg-based battery system, analyzing the evolution of a passivation layer on a Pt substrate by in situ ATR-FTIR spectroscopy. To conduct this experiment, the diamond ATR was coated with Pt, acting as the WE, and the SEC had Mg foil as the CE and Mg wire as a quasi-reference electrode. This study investigated two different electrolytes, 0.25 M EtMgCl-2Et2AlCl (EAC) in tetrahydrofuran (THF), and 0.5 M Mg(TFSA)2 in the ionic butyl methyl triglyme solution (BuMeG3) [55]. The in situ FTIR spectroscopy of the system containing the EAC-based electrolyte was acquired during a CV experiment. The resulting spectra evidenced bands assigned to structural changes on the Pt electrode, specifically downward bands in the range of 1078–860 cm−1 assigned to THF molecules, upward bands at 1062 and 1025 cm−1 attributed to C–O–C stretching vibration, upward bands at 899 and 854 cm−1 attributed to the CH2 wagging vibration mode from THF, and a downward band at 1078 cm−1 attributed to the C–O–C stretching vibration mode from THF. The spectrum presented changes during the cathodic scan from the CV experiment, indicating that THF molecules have gradually formed a surface layer until the system reached the potential of −0.4 V vs. Mg quasi-reference electrode. The spectra showed no significant changes during the beginning of the anodic scan, and the adsorbed species apparently remained on the surface of the platinum electrode. Furthermore, some changes were observed after reaching potentials higher than 1.0 V vs. Mg quasi-reference electrode, presenting that bands were apparently the inverted shape of the spectra acquired during the cathodic scan. Therefore, the authors suggested that the surface layer formed in the system containing the EAC-based electrolyte consisted of the adsorbed or changed THF species near the electrode [55]. Furthermore, the study of the system containing the BuMeG3-based electrolyte was also coupled with a CV experiment. It is observed that upward bands at 1346, 1328, 1041, and 919 cm−1 were attributed to SO2, and bands at 1182 and 759 cm−1 were attributed to CF3 bond from TFSA anion during the initial cathodic scan, which remained until the electrode reached low potentials. Otherwise, spectra showed no clear bands during the anodic scan, indicating that the surface layer appeared during the cathodic scan and remained stable. The authors considered that this surface layer formed on the Pt electrode, during the initial cathodic scan, is a passivation layer since Pt is mostly inactive, differing from the SEI layer from batteries [55]. 3.5 Li-air batteries Li-air is a promissory battery system with an excellent theoretical capacity of ∼3862 A h kg−1 and an energy density of 11,680 W h kg−1 [128–130]. A crucial issue of Li-air batteries is the electrode and electrolyte stability and the control of the discharge product formation/decomposition, restricting their cyclability. Carbonate-based Li-air batteries have their cyclability restricted by their decomposition resulting in Li2CO3. Thus, finding an ideal electrolyte-catalyst to promote long cycle life for these devices is desirable. The development of electrolyte additives, such as mediators, to overcome these issues has been regarded as the last significant development in this technology [130]. Another issue related to the electrolyte is associated with the bulk Li2O2 being electronically insulating, creating an electrically resistant layer on the electrode surface and restricting the capacity for fully filling the pores volume. An alternative to overcome this issue is the use of nanostructured (air) cathodes, with adequate porosity and effective catalysis area distribution, to maximize the use of the material [131]. Electrolyte additives forming new solvents or even newly designed solid catalysts, as presented by Nepel et al. [44], can facilitate the Li2O2 decomposition. The main challenge in Li-air systems is related to tracking multiple chemical changes during cycling processes, such as the formation/decomposition of Li x O y species, electrolyte decomposition, and chemical changes over the electrode surface [132,133]. The electrolyte degradation at the electrode/electrolyte interface is a crucial issue to be further understood. The degradation of Li-air batteries is considered to be caused by a nucleophilic reaction of reduced oxygen species [103,134], particularly by superoxide formed at the positive electrode [65,135]. In this regard, FTIR spectroscopy is a powerful tool to track molecular changes in Li-air batteries. Furthermore, Vivek et al. investigated the reactivity of an electrolyte containing polycarbonate (PC) solvent at a gold electrode by in situ ATR-FTIR spectroscopy. This study aimed to identify the non-catalytic route of superoxide caused by the PC. The electrode-electrolyte interface (i.e., Au/PC-LiClO4) has been investigated under oxygen saturation and deoxygenation conditions. Electrolytes with tetraalkylammonium salt (TEAClO4) instead of lithium salt have also been investigated. The in situ ATR-FTIR spectra of the system containing the PC-TEAClO4 electrolyte showed no significant changes for the PC solvent in the interface. Notably, the spectra of the deoxygenated lithium electrolyte showed C=O stretching bands at an intensity lower than the ones in the spectra of the system containing the PC-TEAClO4 electrolyte. Therefore, Li ions in the electrode/electrolyte interface influenced the PC interaction with the electrode surface. Regarding the negatively polarized electrode, in situ spectra of the system containing the PC-LiClO4 electrolyte showed positive and negative bands with high intensity. The positive bands are assigned to the loss of PC in the interface. In contrast, negative bands are assigned to ring-opened carbonate compounds, i.e., ROCO2Li. The negative bands that appeared at low positive potentials, such as the bands assigned to ROCO2Li in the ranges of 1800–1600 cm−1 and 1400–1200 cm−1 in the spectra of the oxygen-saturated electrolyte and the bands assigned to PC ring-opened species in the range of 1900–1700 cm−1 and 1450–950 cm−1, remained stable under anodic polarization, demonstrating the system stability [65]. The PC ring-opened compounds are present in systems containing PC-based electrolytes, according to the surface layer of Li-air positive electrodes, reported elsewhere [136]. Superoxide compounds from the oxygen reduction at the positive electrode are responsible for this decomposition reaction [65,137,138]. The findings have not indicated the formation of ring-opened compounds in the oxygenated PC-TEAClO4 system, suggesting that Li cations are essential to enable the PC solvent ring-opening reaction and the formation of a surface layer that avoids failures in the Li-air system. Thus, the findings indicated that the PC coordinating Li cations system is essential to reduce the activation obstacle to the ring-opening reaction caused by superoxide [65]. A recent study by Nepel et al. has also demonstrated the remarkable advantage of using in situ micro-nano-FTIR spectroscopy to track chemical changes over the electrode of a Li-air system [44]. This analysis aimed to monitor the effect of atmosphere exposure on the positive carbon electrode. In brief, the authors showed the formation of species (e.g., Li2CO3 and LiOH) [44,139] (Fig. 8 a). These experiments used a novel SEC designed by the authors, which has some similarities with the schematic of the SEC developed by Saqib et al. (Fig. 1b) [42]. The Li-air system investigated by Nepel et al. had a gold (Au) electrode covered with carbon nanotubes (CNTs), shown in Fig. 8(bi). The micrographs of the in situ micro-FTIR spectroscopy indicated significant changes in the positive electrode, meaning the existence of an agglomeration of reaction species (Fig. 8bii) [44]. First, micro-FTIR (ATR-FTIR) spectroscopy and SINS were compared, demonstrating a good correlation between the discharge products at the nanoscale with the average micro-scale of the carbon-based electrode (Fig. 8biii and biv). After the discharge process, the atomic force microscopy (AFM) images of the positive air electrode evidenced an irregular structure of the electrode (insert from Fig. 8biii). The degradation products, such as LiOH, Li2CO3, and Li2O2, observed on the positive electrode surface are dependent on the contact with O2 from the atmosphere [44]. During the discharge process, the resulting micro-FTIR spectra (Fig. 8bv and 8bvi) indicated the presence of novel bands, which have been assigned to the symmetric stretch of the SO2 from dimethyl sulfone (DMSO2), and it is associated with the increase of the intensity of the SO2 asymmetric stretching peaks. Those emerging bands are attributed to the degradation of DMSO species [140–142], which have been detected during the initial minutes of battery operation. The spectra also displayed bands assigned to Li2O2 [143], which are associated with atmospheric conditions [44,144]. 3.6 Zn-air batteries Zinc-air batteries present high energy density and modest cost, but these systems suffer from low cyclability [145,146]. Generally, Zn-air batteries use Zn metal or Zn powder as the negative electrode and a concentrated alkali solution as the electrolyte [56,147]. Zn-air batteries usually employ noble metal catalysts, which present high activity for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), similar to the first studies of Li-air batteries. However, they have been less investigated than Li-Air, and alternatives to noble metal catalysts are still scarce [148]. In situ FTIR spectroscopy can be used to support the design of novel electrocatalysts in the place of noble metals, such as carbon-based electrocatalysts [56,146]. It has been successfully employed to monitor the rate of O2 adsorption from the catalyst reaction of Zn-air batteries. To study a new catalyst for Zn-air battery electrodes, Li et al. investigated a composite material comprising phosphorous-doped cobalt sulfide on a carbon substrate (Co9S8/P@CS) by in situ FTIR spectroscopy [146]. Aiming to study the efficiency of the Co9S8/P@CS catalyst, in situ FTIR spectroscopy was conducted to monitor the O2 adsorption in the range of 1180–1015 cm−1 on the surface of different catalysts, namely: CS/P, Co9S8/P, Co9S8@CS, and Co9S8/P@CS. In situ FTIR spectroscopy demonstrated that the Co9S8/P@CS catalyst presented the highest O2 adsorption during the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) process. Therefore, Co9S8/P was considered the major active site for the catalysis of the OER with the carbon substrate (CS) due to its high conductivity that enabled ion mobility by presenting a brief diffusion path [146]. 3.7 Zn-N2 batteries Aqueous Zn-N2 batteries are an alternative for simultaneous power generation and electrochemical production of (NH3) ammonia, which is an unusual system that has been rarely reported. To reach the electrochemical N2 oxidation, the cathodic nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) must agree with the anodic OER to form a two-electrode structure. In these systems, the Zn oxidation inhibits the generation of O2 during the oxidation of N2. Thus, the scarcity of oxygen evolution decreases the cyclability of Zn-N2 batteries, restricting their potential applications. In this context, the proper design of electrocatalysts can provide an efficient NRR-OER activity, providing stability to the system. Metal phosphates have been considered appropriate materials for the cathodes of Zn-N2 batteries, such as cobalt phosphate, which has been considered an efficient electrocatalyst, presenting an adequate OER performance [149–151]. In situ FTIR spectroscopy can contribute to the development of novel catalyst materials for positive electrodes of Zn-N2 batteries by tracking the catalytic reaction route [149,150]. A study by Ren et al. investigated a secondary Zn-N2 battery system employing cobalt phosphate nanocrystals-loaded heteroatoms-doped carbon nanosheets (CoPi/NPCS) as the positive electrode catalyst, reducing N2 to NH3 [149]. This technique identified the formation of N2H y intermediates on the CoPi/NPCS surface [149], which was previously reported [152,153]. The authors investigated the chronoamperometry curves (Fig. 9 a), and they observed that the current for the CoPi/NPCS fluctuated after the addition of the SCN-aqueous solution to the electrolyte. Also, the current density of CoPi/NPCS dropped constantly during analysis. Meanwhile, the NH3 rate from the CoPi/NPCS was reduced at −0.3 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE), resulting from blocked Co sites that were reducing the active area of the NRR [149]. Furthermore, Ren et al. [151] conducted in situ FTIR spectroscopy (Fig. 9b) to monitor reactions of the CoP/NPCS catalyst throughout the electrochemical N2 fixation (Fig. 9c). The bands monitored during this process were assigned to H–N–H bending, –NH2 wagging, and N–N stretching vibration bonds, which were at 1,495, 1,295, and 1,071 cm−1, respectively (Fig. 9b) [151,154,155]. The magnitude of these bands increased during the reaction, showing the accumulation of reaction intermediates [149,151,155]. These changes in the bands enabled the identification of the N2H y formation, whose y value ranges from 1 to 4, on the CoPi/NPCS [149,151,152]. In summary, the in situ FTIR characterization technique identified the catalytic reaction pathway of the NRR process, which can contribute to a deeper understanding of Zn-N2 batteries electrochemistry. The authors proposed a reaction mechanism for the CoPi/NPCS NRR process pathway based on the FTIR spectra results (Fig. 9d), which starts with protons coupled with N2, generating N2H y intermediates and producing NH3. Initially, a N2 molecule reaches the surface of CoPi/NPCS, which is absorbed by the Co sites (when they are positively charged), creating Co–N≡N bonds. This process is followed by the transfer of a proton from an adjacent phosphate group and an electron to produce –N≡N–H bonds. Then, the active –N≡N–H bonds are hydrogenated by the protons and electrons, forming N2H4 intermediates. Next, a free NH3 molecule is formed from N2H4 active sites, followed by the formation of another NH3 molecule on CoPi/NPCS. 3.8 Sodium-ion batteries Na-ion battery (SIB) is a promising technology, and sodium is a material abundant on the earth [156,157]. Slater et al. emphasized that SIBs would present a lower cost than lithium batteries, and they could be a complementary choice for LIBs in the future [158]. However, even if these devices present intercalation chemistry resembling lithium, the further research on new materials is necessary since Na+ ions are larger than Li+ [158,159]. In this context, organic materials present architectural flexibility and can also be employed in sodium-ion devices since they facilitate sodium cations migration kinetics [160–162]. The further analysis of these materials storage mechanisms was reported by Kim et al., which presented a considerable research on organic electrodes for SIBs [163]. Stevens et al. primarily introduced the use of hard carbon as a negative electrode [164], which is commonly employed in SIBs research, and they considered positive electrodes such as layered oxides and polyanionic species [157]. The SIBs can be an alternative for energy storage, but their electrochemical performance must be improved [156]. In this scenario, ex situ and in situ FTIR spectroscopy can be employed to investigate sodium storage mechanisms and study new materials for SIBs by tracking the effects of the insertion and extraction of sodium ions and monitoring the system stability [61]. Inorganic electrodes may have issues with the insertion/extraction of Na+ ions [165–167]. On the other hand, organic electrodes can present outstanding Na+ mobility kinetics [160–162]. Furthermore, Yin et al. monitored reactions of a cobalt-based coordination polymer (Co-MA-3) anode in a half-cell configuration during the sodiation and desodiation processes by in situ ATR-FTIR spectroscopy (see the schematic in Fig. 10 a and the charge-discharge profile in Fig. 10b). This experiment monitored bands assigned to the electrolyte decomposition and C=O vibration bond from C=O groups of the Co-MA-3 electrode, demonstrating a sodium storage reaction with C=O group, which presented a reversible behavior of the C=O bands (Fig. 10c). This approach attested the Co-MA-3 high ion/electron diffusion, which had a shape similar to purple flower-like microspheres (Fig. 10d). The authors also suggested that the sodium storage mechanism of the Co-MA-3 was related to the oxygen center of the C=O bond (one sodium ion per C=O), enabling sodium insertion and extraction in the oxygen centers of the carbonyl compound (Fig. 10e) [61]. 4 Conclusions Energy storage devices are being highly demanded by various sectors leveraged by the energy transition. Innovating and improving these devices are required and can further foster these markets. The progress in the research on batteries is essential to provide in-depth knowledge of elemental chemistry and the charge storage mechanisms of these devices for the development of novel materials. In this scenario, in situ and operando characterization can be a powerful tool since they can monitor structural changes in systems under operating conditions, contributing to the ongoing battery research. These characterization techniques have been improved and used for battery research in recent years. In this review, there are descriptions of some in situ and operando FTIR representative studies applied to battery systems describing the experimental approach, cell design, operation principles, and results. The review shows that in situ and operando FTIR spectroscopies could support electrode design for LIBs by tracking chemical reactions in the electrode-electrolyte interface. Promising positive electrodes, such as LMO, LMP, and NMC, and negative electrodes, such as carbon-based electrodes and silicon, could be better understood by FTIR spectroscopy since it can monitor structural changes in the electrode-electrolyte interface, such as the formation of novel species resulting from the electrolyte solvent reduction (e.g., LiEDC and DEDOHC), monitor materials stability, trace possible degradation mechanisms, and define safe operating conditions. Furthermore, in situ and operando FTIR spectroscopies can support the development of systems beyond lithium batteries, which could be a considerable advantage considering the supply shortage and increasing price of lithium. This review presents successful applications of in situ and operando FTIR studies in this work, providing valuable information about several processes, such as: (i) monitoring the polysulfide formation and supporting the development of materials that suppress the shuttle effect of Li-S batteries, (ii) observing the electrolyte reduction and reversibility of Na-ion batteries, (iii) following the formation of surface layers on composite electrodes of Mg-metal batteries, and (iv) studying the electrocatalytic reactions of Zn-air and Z-N2 batteries, as summarized by Fig. 11 . Other spectroscopy characterization techniques, such as Raman and UV-vis spectroscopies (not addressed in this review), are also extremely useful and can render complementary information to FTIR spectroscopy. This review has also highlighted that the SEC employed can highly influence the analysis and the better choice depends exclusively on the experiment’s aim. In this context, versatile SECs are desirable since they enable carrying out other in situ and operando techniques, such as Raman spectroscopy or XRD, precisely studying the same system using complementary techniques. Apart from conventional in situ FTIR experiments, this review includes the more challenging imaging experiments. Improvements in mapping/imaging using FTIR and Raman—as well as progress on nano-micro FTIR spectroscopy, such as SINS—are necessary to spread this technique, which may highly contribute to the development of energy storage devices in the future. However, this review focuses on conventional approaches since the experiments can be performed with widely available conventional FTIR spectrometers [66]; as shown in this review, they can provide extremely useful results. Finally, since the technique is not extensively spread in the field and has been used several times by non-experts, it is important to be careful during the interpretation of the data and assignment of the bands. Whenever possible, individual spectra of the electrolyte components (in some specific cases of the electrode) must be obtained in conditions as similar as possible to those in a real device. However, this “best practices” protocol is not often followed in this field. Hopefully, this review can contribute to the establishment of in situ and operando FTIR spectroscopy as a protocol for monitoring the development of materials for batteries and novel battery systems in the future. Also, the research in versatile SECs applied to batteries should still progress, aiming to obtain systems appropriate for battery setup, either half-cell or full-cell. coredata.dc:description: In situ and operando infrared spectroscopies are powerful techniques to support the design of novel materials for batteries and the development of new battery systems. These techniques can support the study of batteries by identifying the formation of new species and monitoring electrochemical energy stability. However, few works have employed these techniques, which can be used to investigate various materials, including systems beyond lithium-ion technology, in the research of batteries. Therefore, this review presents a comprehensive overview focusing on the main contributions of in situ and operando infrared spectroscopy for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and other battery systems. These techniques can successfully identify the formation of species during the electrolyte reduction, electrode degradation, and the formation of the solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer. From these outcomes, it is possible to conclude that this characterization approach should be employed as a protocol to overcome remaining issues in batteries, consequently supporting battery research. This review aims to be a guide on how infrared spectroscopy can contribute to monitoring battery systems and to lead researchers interested in applying this technique.
